Situation1: Got a request to attend court to provide testimony when required.
Expectation2: Recite and reflect on the Quran
Situation2: The community study circle convenes tonight to discuss verses the person has not yet read.
Story: I sat at my desk, the court summons heavy in my hand. As a police officer, I knew my duty was clear: I must testify honestly, upholding the law with integrity and fairness. The trial was scheduled for tomorrow, and tonight I needed to review my notes, prepare my mind, and ensure my testimony would be precise and just. Yet, as a Muslim, tonight was also the weekly study circle at the mosque. The community would gather to recite and reflect on the Quran, and this week’s verses were ones I hadn’t yet read. I felt the weight of expectation from my faith—to be present, to learn, to grow spiritually with my brothers and sisters. My heart tugged in two directions: the call of justice and the call of faith. I stared at the clock, feeling the pressure mount, knowing that whatever I chose, I would be letting down a part of myself and the people who depended on me.
